Review Recent progress in functional carbon-based materials for advanced electrocatalysis Yinglong Weng b d Jianping Zhang b Kun Zhang a * Yitong Lu a b Tingting Huang b Yingbo Kang d Xiaotong Han b * Jieshan Qiu c * a School of Chemical Engineering, Northeast Electric Power University, Jilin 132012, Jilin, China School of Chemical Engineering Northeast Electric Power University Jilin Jilin 132012 China School of Chemical Engineering, Northeast Electric Power University, Jilin 132012, Jilin, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 401331, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Chongqing University Chongqing 401331 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 401331, China c State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering College of Chemical Engineering Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China d School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Liaoning University of Technology, Jinzhou 121001, Liaoning, China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering Liaoning University of Technology Jinzhou Liaoning 121001 China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Liaoning University of Technology, Jinzhou 121001, Liaoning, China * Corresponding author Functional carbon-based materials have become a key research direction in the field of advanced electrocatalysis due to their unique structure and properties. Various strategies have been proposed to design and synthesize high-performance carbon-based electrocatalysts. In this review, we comprehensively summarize the latest developments in carbon-based materials for advanced electrocatalysis, with particular emphasis on the structure design strategies and the intrinsic relationship between structure, activity, and performance. The functionalization of multi-dimensional carbon-based materials with enhanced electrocatalytic performance is first addressed. Next, the impact of electronic and structural engineering on the performance of carbon-based materials for electrocatalysis is discussed in terms of the advantages of different types of carbon-based materials in electrocatalytic applications. Finally, the prospects in areas such as precise tuning of functional carbon-based materials, the development of renewable carbon materials, the use of advanced characterization techniques and the promotion of smart manufacturing and responsiveness are highlighted. Graphical Abstract This article provides a comprehensive review of the latest research advances on carbon-based materials in the field of electrocatalysis, highlighting the impact of their structural design, electronic engineering, and functional modifications on catalytic performance. Keywords Carbon materials Functionalization Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction The energy crisis and environmental challenges associated with fossil fuels have accelerated the development of green, efficient, and sustainable energy technologies [1,2]. Among various renewable energy solutions, electrochemical energy conversion and storage systems, such as water splitting, carbon dioxide reduction, nitrogen reduction, fuel cells, and metal-air batteries, are widely regarded as essential technologies for achieving sustainable development [3,4]. These electrochemical conversion processes rely on typical redox reactions, including the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) during water splitting, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in fuel cells or metal-air batteries, as well as the carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), which convert low-value substances into high-value products [5–7]. The rate of these reactions is constrained by their inherently slow kinetics, often necessitating high overpotentials to achieve the desired current density. To overcome this limitation, researchers are focusing on the design and optimization of efficient electrocatalysts. Among various electrocatalysts, platinum (Pt) and other precious metals, such as rhodium (Rh), iridium (Ir), palladium (Pd), and ruthenium (Ru), are widely regarded as ideal due to their exceptional intrinsic electrocatalytic performance. However, the scarcity, high cost, poor stability, and susceptibility to CO poisoning-induced deactivation of these precious metal electrocatalysts significantly hinder their large-scale commercial application in electrocatalysis [8–11]. As a result, the development of electrocatalysts that offer high electrocatalytic activity, enhanced stability, low cost, and abundant availability has become a key area of ongoing research. Additionally, the design of non-metallic electrocatalysts and those with minimal precious metal content has gained increasing attention. Among various energy conversion materials, carbon-based materials (such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, carbon quantum dots, fullerenes, activated carbon, etc.) exhibit significant advantages due to their unique structural characteristics. Compared to traditional support materials, these materials not only have a high specific surface area and excellent conductivity, but also offer low cost, controllable preparation processes, and outstanding chemical stability, making them promising candidate materials for electrocatalysts with broad application potential [12]. To further enhance their intrinsic electrocatalytic performance, researchers have utilized various chemical and physical methods to precisely modify and functionalize carbon materials. This flexible tuning ability allows carbon-based materials to exhibit specific performance advantages across various application domains [13]. Furthermore, carbon materials possess a diverse range of physicochemical properties and are widely employed as multi-dimensional frameworks to support nanomaterials [14]. Carbon-supported composites not only inherit the excellent properties of the carbon materials but also significantly enhance the dispersion and structural stability of the guest materials. In the field of electrocatalysis, carbon-supported materials hold exciting potential, with widespread applications in ORR, OER, HER, CO2RR and NRR [15,16]. More importantly, the use of carbon-supported materials in electrocatalytic biochemical synthesis has attracted considerable attention, emerging as a prominent area of research. In this review, we provide a comprehensive summary of recent advancements in carbon-based materials for electrocatalysis, with a particular emphasis on their structural design strategies and the interplay between structure, activity, and performance. Initially, we highlight the contributions to the chemical modification and development of multi-dimensional carbon materials. Subsequently, we discuss the role of electronic and structural engineering in tailoring carbon materials for electrocatalysis. Recent progress in their applications is systematically reviewed, covering key reactions such as ORR, OER, HER, CO2RR, NRR, and bio-chemical synthesis. Finally, we present perspectives on existing technical challenges and future directions for the advancement of carbon-based electrocatalysts in energy conversion and storage. We anticipate that this comprehensive analysis will provide valuable insights for researchers working toward the design of high-performance, cost-effective carbon materials for sustainable energy technologies (Fig. 1 ). 2 Functionalization of multidimensional carbon-based materials Functionalized carbon materials grafted with modification agents, including organic molecules, polymers, and oxygen-containing groups, have been extensively developed and applied in the field of energy storage and conversion [17–19]. Rational control over surface chemistry enables the modulation of surface hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity, thereby achieving tunable microstructures and properties of carbon materials (Figs. 1(A)–(D)). In recent years, substantial efforts have been dedicated to the chemical modification and functionalization of multi-dimensional carbon materials, with a focus on their applications in electrocatalysis, solar cells, and electrochemical energy fields [20–22]. In this section, we will discuss contributions to the chemical and structural modifications of functionalized carbon materials across zero to three dimensions and provide in-depth insights into their roles for electrocatalysis. 2.1 Zero-dimensional (0D) carbon materials Carbon quantum dots (CQDs), a representative 0D carbon nanomaterial, have garnered significant attention due to their minimal toxicity, distinctive electronic properties, and excellent chemical stability [27]. Extensive research has focused on synthesizing CQDs from diverse carbon precursors, with coal emerging as a particularly advantageous choice owing to its unique characteristics. Typically, CQDs are prepared via heat treatment of coal precursors in the presence of strong oxidizing acids [28]. The size of coal-derived CQDs can be precisely controlled by adjusting the carbonization temperature and the graphitic crystalline structure of the coal [29]. Furthermore, acidic oxidation introduces functional groups, such as carbonyl (C=O) and epoxy (C–O) groups, on the surfaces and edges of the CQDs, enhancing their fluorescence emissions at longer wavelengths (Fig. 2(A) ). The negatively charged surfaces of CQDs enable their application as carriers for stabilizing nanoparticles in polar solvents. For example, carboxylic groups on CQDs can graft onto PbTe nanoparticle surfaces, while residual oxygen-containing groups facing the solvent undergo deprotonation [30]. This process increases solvation energy, mitigating nanoparticle agglomeration. Additionally, CQDs have been employed to confine unsaturated Zn and Cu species. Theoretical calculations suggest that this confinement arises through the chelation of Zn and Cu species with the CQD matrix, forming Cu-O(N)-Zn-O(N)-Cu complexes (Fig. 2(A1)) [23]. The carbon framework of CQDs facilitates electron exchange between confined metal sites, thereby enhancing their electron-donating and -accepting capabilities. To further functionalize CQDs, an amide-bond-bridging strategy has been introduced, linking CQDs with organic amino molecules. The hydrophilic or hydrophobic nature of functionalized CQDs is influenced by the hydrocarbon chain length of the amino molecules, enabling high dispersion in either water or organic solvents (Fig. 2(A2)) [17]. Additionally, the modified CQDs exhibit significantly higher quantum yields compared to their pristine counterparts [31]. A novel approach employing gravitational fields has also been developed to couple CQDs with carbon spheres. By adjusting gravitational field strength, the concentration and distribution of CQDs on carbon sphere surfaces can be precisely regulated, allowing for controlled defect density and electron transfer properties in carbon-conjugated CQDs. This gravity-sensitive behavior was found to enhance edge carbon sites, leading to increased charge density and improved electronic properties. These features were particularly beneficial for triiodide reduction, as confirmed by both experimental and theoretical analyses. Due to the size effect and high specific surface area, 0D carbon materials exhibit good performance in certain electrocatalytic reactions, such as ORR and HER. 2.2 One-dimensional (1D) carbon materials 1D carbon nanotubes (CNTs), characterized by their unique tubular structures, have garnered significant attention due to their exceptional electrical conductivity and chemical stability [32]. However, their poor dispersibility in solvents poses challenges for practical manipulation. Chemical modification has emerged as an effective approach to alter the surface properties and polarities of CNTs, attracting extensive research efforts (Fig. 2(B)). Recently, a straightforward chemical strategy was developed to enhance the surface properties of CNTs using polyelectrolytes [33]. It was observed that the dispersibility of polymer-modified CNTs improved significantly with increasing diblock copolymer chain length. Additionally, a mixed acid oxidation method has been proposed, which introduces a substantial number of oxygen-containing functional groups on the CNT surface. The oxidized CNTs exhibit excellent dispersibility, and their negatively charged functional groups can adsorb positively charged metal ions, making them highly versatile for applications across various fields. Further advancements include the development of one-dimensional carbon nanoribbons (CNRs) through the chemical unzipping of CNTs. These CNRs feature abundant edge sites and fully exposed basal planes, allowing for the facile doping of nitrogen species into their backbones (Fig. 2(B1)). These structural and compositional modifications significantly enhance their electrochemical activity [34]. Moreover, the preservation of oxygen-containing functional groups within the CNR structure renders them promising as supports for guest nanomaterial deposition, offering potential for future exploration [21]. Quasi-1D hollow carbon nanorods have also been synthesized via a sacrificial template method using poly-dopamine as a carbon source. These hollow nanorods have been utilized as supports for encapsulating cobalt nanoparticles [24]. The hollow carbon framework serves as an effective host scaffold to confine sulfur and polysulfides in lithium-sulfur batteries. Furthermore, the encapsulated cobalt nanoparticles modulate the electronic structure of the hollow carbon matrix, facilitating the chemical adsorption of lithium sulfides (Fig. 2(B2)). This structural synergy leads to enhanced battery performance, characterized by high rate capability and superior cycling stability. Therefore, the structure of one-dimensional carbon materials allows them to exhibit high conductivity and excellent electron transport properties in electrocatalytic reactions, making them particularly suitable as electrode materials for electrocatalysis. 2.3 Two-dimensional (2D) carbon materials Graphene, a prototypical 2D carbon material, exhibits numerous advantages, including a large theoretical specific surface area, excellent electrical conductivity, and superior mechanical and thermal stability [35]. Similar to CNTs, functionalization is a prerequisite for employing graphene as a support material. Recently, an electrochemical activation strategy was developed to exfoliate and functionalize graphite foil in a NiSO4 electrolyte. This process produced graphene sheets with an average thickness of approximately 4.7 nm, indicative of their few-layer structure. Simultaneously, electronegative oxygen-containing functional groups were introduced into the graphene backbone through electrochemical activation (Fig. 2(C)). The oxygen content was adjustable by varying the applied voltage, enabling precise control over the functionalization. These oxygen species facilitated the anchoring of Ni atoms via Ni–O6 coordination, resulting in an oxygen-coordinated Ni single-atom electrocatalyst. Notably, this approach is highly time-efficient (1.5 min) and scalable for the large-scale production of functionalized graphene sheets and single-atom materials [19]. Graphene oxide (GO), a well-known functionalized 2D carbon material, features extensive oxygen functionalization but suffers from significantly reduced electrical conductivity due to its high oxygen content (Fig. 2(C1)). To address this limitation, a thermal expansion reduction strategy was introduced to partially reduce GO by removing most oxygen functional groups, thereby restoring its high electrical conductivity [36–38]. Remarkably, some residual functional groups remained on the surface of the reduced GO, preserving its chemical reactivity. Additionally, the reduced GO exhibited a hierarchical structure with numerous macropores, providing spatially confined skeletons for the deposition of guest nanomaterials. Further advancements included the design of polymer-modified graphene using polyaniline as a surface modification material. The resulting graphene exhibited negatively charged surfaces due to nitrogen- and oxygen-containing species derived from polyaniline (Fig. 2(C2)). This modification facilitated the adsorption of metal ions through complexation and electrostatic interactions. Moreover, polyaniline served as a structural coupling bridge, mediating the nucleation and assembly of metal hydroxide nanosheets. This process promoted the vertically oriented growth of ultrathin nanosheets with abundant active sites and well-defined open frameworks, enhancing their potential for various electrocatalytic applications [18]. In summary, 2D carbon materials play a crucial role as catalyst supports and reaction interfaces in electrocatalytic reactions. 2.4 Three-dimensional (3D) carbon materials 3D carbon materials, characterized by high electrical conductivity, well-defined interconnected porous networks, and macroscopic monolithic structures, have found extensive applications as substrates for supporting guest nanomaterials (Fig. 2(D)). Among these, carbon fibers have attracted significant attention in recent years. For example, a flexible 3D activated carbon fabric composed of carbon nanofibers with diameters of approximately 300 nm was developed through electrospinning, using polyacrylonitrile as the carbon precursor (Fig. 2(D1)) [25]. This carbon fabric exhibits a large surface area, high adsorption capacity, and excellent mechanical flexibility, enabling the facile growth of guest nanomaterials on its surface. Notably, guest nanomaterials can also be in-situ anchored onto the activated carbon nanofiber structure during the electrospinning process. The size, composition, and distribution of these guest materials can be precisely controlled, and the stability of the resulting composites is enhanced due to the strong binding interactions between the guest nanomaterials and the carbon nanofibers [39]. Furthermore, the surface of carbon fibers can be rationally modified through chemical oxidation and oxygen plasma treatment (Fig. 2(D2)). These functionalization strategies impart strong hydrophilicity to the carbon fibers, facilitating the controlled and well-ordered growth of guest materials via methods such as chemical deposition, electrodeposition, and hydrothermal synthesis. Additionally, nitrogen-doped carbon layers have been employed as surface modifiers to functionalize 3D carbon cloth [26]. These nitrogen-doped layers act as “nanoglue” forming superhydrophilic surfaces and interfaces that promote the robust and uniform growth of guest nanomaterials on the substrate. Benefiting from the structure of 3D carbon materials, which provides a larger reaction interface and facilitates effective contact between reactants and catalysts, 3D carbon materials are widely used in electrochemical energy storage (such as supercapacitors and batteries) and electrocatalysis. They offer advantages such as high catalytic efficiency and long service life. 2.5 Hierarchical carbon materials The integration of electrocatalysts into hierarchical carbon structures enables exceptional multifunctionality, particularly in fine-tuning electrocatalytic active sites and electronic properties. These innovative materials utilize carbon-based frameworks such as porous carbon, graphene, and carbon nanotubes, which are combined with electrocatalytic components like transition metals, oxides, and nitrides. This hybridization creates complex, multilayered architectures with versatile functionalities. Thoughtful architectural design not only boosts the density of active sites but also enhances charge transfer capabilities and improves reactant adsorption, ultimately driving greater efficiency and selectivity in electrocatalytic applications. For instance, an integrated Pt x Co y @NCNTs electrocatalyst has been developed, where Co atoms are incorporated into the Pt lattice via a thermally-driven strategy on a sea cucumber-like N-doped carbon matrix [40]. This unique sea cucumber-inspired hierarchical hollow N-doped carbon matrix, abundant in N-doped carbon nanotubes, exhibits a high specific surface area and an excellent conductive network, significantly enhancing the accessibility of active sites. Moreover, the synergistic interactions between carbon materials and electrocatalytic components are critical for improving performance. For example, metal single-atom catalysts (SACs) can be uniformly dispersed on carbon surfaces, optimizing the coordination environment of metal atoms and enhancing electrocatalytic activity [41]. Metal oxides or nitrides further modify the electronic structure of carbon materials, improving electron and proton transfer during electrocatalytic processes. This multiscale hybrid strategy not only enhances the selectivity and stability of electrocatalytic reactions but also significantly prolongs the lifespan, maintaining superior performance under harsh conditions. In addition to their exceptional energy conversion capabilities, these hierarchical carbon structure materials hold great promise in environmental protection, pollution control, and carbon capture applications, underscoring their potential for addressing critical global challenges. 3 Electronic and structural engineering of carbon-based materials 3.1 Heteroatom doping engineering The electronic states of electrocatalytic active sites are critical to the intrinsic activity of carbon materials [42–44]. Favorable electronic properties, such as optimal electron density and band structure, play a pivotal role in facilitating reactant adsorption and product desorption, thereby significantly enhancing electrocatalytic efficiency [45,46]. By introducing suitable foreign atoms near the active sites, the electronic structure of carbon-based electrocatalysts can be precisely regulated at the atomic and molecular levels. This approach not only overcomes the inherent chemical inertness of carbon materials but also effectively adjusts their electronic structure, thereby markedly improving electrocatalytic activity [47,48]. Studies have shown that doping with heteroatoms effectively modulates the electronic properties of carbon materials, such as electron cloud density and HOMO/LUMO energy levels, enhancing their reactivity. Incorporating heteroatoms with varying electronegativities into carbon materials can generate multiple active centers, demonstrating excellent electrocatalytic performance. For example, Gao et al. [49] investigated the application of nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxide for the selective oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone in aqueous media. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that active oxygen species were not directly formed near the nitrogen sites but rather on adjacent carbon atoms, which exhibited remarkable electrocatalytic activity, leading to the generation of active oxygen on the carbon surface. This phenomenon was attributed to nitrogen doping, which notably altered the charge distribution and density of states of neighboring carbon atoms [49]. Co-doping with multiple heteroatoms has proven to be an effective approach for modulating the electronic structure of active sites and enhancing the electrocatalytic activity of carbon materials. The incorporation of different heteroatoms into carbon materials induces structural distortions and significant changes in charge density, generating unique local electronic effects at active sites [50,51]. Notably, introducing heteroatoms with markedly different electronegativities can result in electron withdrawal or donation, thereby influencing the electronic structure of the active sites. Meng et al. [48] conducted a DFT study to investigate the incorporation of boron (B), nitrogen (N), and phosphorus (P) atoms into carbon layers and their electronic properties (Figs. 3(A) –(C)). They examined the effects of weakly electronegative boron (B, 2.04) and strongly electronegative nitrogen (N, 3.04) on the electrocatalytic activity of phosphorus-doped carbon (PC) materials. The study revealed that the electronegativity disparity between B and N significantly altered the electronic structure of P=O active sites and adjacent carbon atoms [52]. Density of states analysis showed that B-doped PC materials exhibited a shift in the electronic center toward the Fermi level, accompanied by a marked increase in electron density near the Fermi level. This indicated that B doping enhanced the electronic activity of BPC materials compared to NPC materials (Figs. 3(D) and (E)). 3.2 Functional group grafting engineering Compared to heteroatom doping, introducing functional groups with varying electronegativity or conjugated properties onto the carbon matrix offers greater potential for modulating charge density distribution, interlayer spacing, and morphology. Studies on the regulatory effects of electron-accepting and electron-donating functional groups reveal that the microstructure, interlayer spacing, morphology, and performance of carbon materials are closely tied to the type, quantity, and positioning of these groups. Gao et al. [53] successfully incorporated the strongly electron-accepting cyano (–CN) group into two-dimensional nitrogen-doped graphene (GDY) by precisely controlling both the number and positions of these functional groups. By varying the number of cyano groups substituting acetylene groups at different positions on the hexylbenzene molecule, they synthesized GDY derivatives containing one cyano group (CNGDY), two meta-cyano groups (m-CNGDY), and two para-cyano groups (p-CNGDY). Experimental results demonstrated that the positional and numerical variations of cyano groups effectively influenced the planar morphology and interlayer spacing of GDY. Band structure and density of states analyses further revealed that the nitrogen atoms in the cyano groups modified the electronic distribution around the carbon atoms, facilitating electron-hole pair separation. In m-CNGDY, the nitrogen atoms, acting as electron acceptors, lowered the highest occupied state of the valence band (VB). In contrast, in p-CNGDY, only a limited number of electrons were locally concentrated around the nitrogen atoms, resulting in a significant difference in the optical bandgap between m-CNGDY and p-CNGDY. Surface oxidation of carbon materials to introduce specific oxygen-containing functional groups is a widely employed strategy to enhance their electrocatalytic performance. Song et al. [54,55] developed a carboxylated hexagonal boron nitride/graphene (h-BN/G) heterojunction structure on commercial activated carbon (AC) by coupling boron (B) and nitrogen (N) co-doping with surface oxygen functionalization. Boric acid and dicyandiamide served as boron and nitrogen precursors, respectively, and were combined with activated carbon before pyrolysis to synthesize the h-BN/G heterojunction (Figs. 4(A)‒(E) ). Nitric acid oxidation was then applied to introduce carboxyl groups, resulting in the carboxylated h-BN/G structure. In-situ Raman spectroscopy and theoretical calculations revealed that this structure significantly enhanced the adsorption and stabilization of key intermediates. By lowering the energy barrier of the rate-determining step, the carboxylated h-BN/G structure effectively improved the electrocatalytic reaction. Electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups on the edges and surfaces of carbon materials, such as amino (–NH2), carboxyl (–COO), hydroxyl (–OH), and various nitrogen dopants, have been identified as critical factors in optimizing active sites [56–58]. Li et al. developed a two-dimensional graphene-like nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheet (N–CN) using a freeze-drying technique, which significantly increased the specific surface area, enhanced its graphitization, and elevated the atomic ratio of electron-donating groups. During the freeze-drying process, the concentration of electron-donating groups in N-CN continuously increased. Experimental analyses revealed a substantial decrease in electron-withdrawing C–O single bonds and a corresponding increase in electron-donating N–H bonds after the freeze-drying treatment. To investigate adsorption sites, the projected density of states calculations for adsorbed intermediates indicated that, among various doped graphene materials, the electronic states of active carbon atoms near the Fermi level were predominantly contributed by p z orbitals. In two-dimensional graphene, the p x and p y orbitals form σ bonds through sp 2 hybridization, connecting adjacent carbon atoms, while the p z orbitals, oriented perpendicular to the graphene plane, play a key role in bonding interactions with surface-adsorbed molecules. A higher density of p z states further enhances vertical bonding capabilities. Overall, the abundant electron-donating surface groups, such as –NH2 and –OH, effectively modify the electronic structure of adjacent carbon atoms, strengthening the adsorption of intermediates and improving electrocatalytic activity. The strategy of directly modifying molecular catalysts through axial coordination with functionalized carbon materials has proven advantageous for electrocatalysis. Carbon-based materials often possess diverse surface functional groups, such as hydroxyl, carbonyl, and carboxyl groups. Furthermore, these materials can be doped or functionalized to incorporate other elements, such as nitrogen and sulfur. Sun et al. [59] developed a series of functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes (CNTs). During the functionalization process, they grafted in-situ generated 4-amino-pyridine and 4-amino-thiophene azide salts onto the CNTs, producing N- and S-functionalized pyridine-modified multi-walled CNTs (Py-CNTs) and S-modified multi-walled CNTs (S-CNTs). For oxygen-functionalized CNTs, they successfully generated Py-O-CNTs (N-O functionalized multi-walled CNTs) by oxidizing the pyridine groups on Py-CNTs with H2O2. Subsequently, they mixed the CoIICNPY with these functionalized CNTs (Figs. 4(G) and (H)). Raman spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) confirmed the successful immobilization of CoIICNPY, resulting in a heterogeneous electrocatalyst. They found that CoIICNPY likely became electronically enriched through axial coordination with N, O, and S, which provided electron density to the Co atoms, shifting them to a lower binding energy state. This observation aligns with the electronegativity of N, O, and S. Axial coordination enhanced the electron density around the Co atoms. Furthermore, the projected density of states calculations revealed that the d orbitals of the Co atoms underwent reorganization, with significant electronic state changes near the Fermi level. This led to the formation of semi-metallic characteristics, lowering the energy barrier and potentially improving the electrocatalytic activity. 3.3 Interface engineering Interface engineering plays a crucial role in enhancing the performance of hybrid materials by leveraging synergistic effects to overcome kinetic and activity limitations in electrocatalysis [60]. The strong coupling between different components at heterointerfaces facilitates efficient electron and intermediate transfer. By precisely tuning carbon-substrate interfaces, it is possible to optimize adsorption/desorption steps and modulate the energy barriers of rate-determining steps. Electronic metal-support interactions (EMSIs) provide an effective strategy for modulating the electronic structure of metals, significantly enhancing their electrocatalytic efficiency [61–63]. For instance, Deng et al. [64] fabricated a defective carbon support by Ar+ sputtering high-oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) and subsequently growing sub-2 nm Ag on its surface. XPS revealed the presence of an Ag δ+ feature, indicating strong EMSIs and substantial charge transfer (Fig. 5(G) ). DFT calculations further demonstrated the charge transfer from Ag clusters to the carbon surface, which stabilized the COOH intermediate, lowering its formation energy barrier by 0.41 eV (Figs. 5(H) and (I)). Graphdiyne (GDY), a newly emerging carbon allotrope featuring aromatic rings and carbon–carbon triple bonds, exhibits strong π–π conjugation and exceptional electron transfer capabilities [65]. Yu et al. [66] demonstrated that Cu2O nanoclusters anchored on GDY exhibit strong electronic interactions, stabilizing Cu2O in a low oxidation state while optimizing the adsorption energy of reactants. XPS analysis confirmed the formation of Cu–C bonds and an unconventional electron transfer direction from Cu2O to GDY. DFT calculations further validated the presence of strong electronic oxide-graphdiyne interactions, which enhance electrocatalytic efficiency by tuning the electronic structure of the active sites. The electrocatalytic activity of transition metals and carbon composites is strongly influenced by the electronic structure of the transition metal center, particularly the configuration of its 3d orbitals. In an octahedral crystal field, these orbitals split into low-energy t 2g and high-energy e g orbitals, with electron transitions between them determining the spin state [67]. This spin state, in turn, directly affects reactant adsorption and reaction thermodynamics. High-spin states are particularly beneficial for oxygen-involved electrocatalytic processes, as they enhance orbital overlap and strengthen interactions with oxygen-containing reactants [68]. Researchers have explored various strategies to regulate spin states, including controlling the microenvironment of the metal center, tuning particle size and crystallinity, and introducing structural defects [69]. Li et al. [70] introduced a microwave–assisted spin control strategy to prepare Co3O4 encapsulated in a graphene shell (Figs. 5(A)‒(C)). The rapid temperature fluctuations induced by microwave thermal shock reduced the particle size and strengthened interactions between Co and nitrogen-doped graphene. DFT and XAS analyses confirmed that the high-spin Co species led to electron enrichment on the graphene shell, improving electron mobility and enhancing orbital overlap with reactants. This facilitates efficient electron transfer, shifting the d-band center and e g orbital levels closer to the Fermi level (Figs. 5(D)‒(F)). Additionally, the electron-rich graphene shell not only promoted intermediates adsorption but also activated the intermediates via non-radical pathways, accelerating reaction kinetics and enhancing oxidation efficiency [70]. 3.4 Edge and defect engineering The edge and defect sites of carbon materials have been a prominent area of research due to their substantial influence on electronic properties and surface reactivity. Numerous studies have demonstrated that edge structures and intrinsic defects are critical to the performance of carbon–based materials, particularly as highly effective electrocatalytic centers. Evidence suggests that edge sites play a pivotal role in determining the electrocatalytic efficiency of carbon materials, especially in the context of heteroatom doping [71,72]. For example, ball–milling graphite with S8 selectively functionalizes the edges with sulfur, resulting in a significant enhancement of oxygen electrocatalysis. DFT calculations indicate that sulfur atoms or sulfur oxides bonded to edge covalent sites are key contributors to improved electrocatalytic performance. In addition, Yang et al. [73] employed a nanocutting technique to modify multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), producing hybrids of nanoribbons and nanotubes with varying edge content. Their investigation revealed a strong correlation between the electrical conductivity of the electrocatalyst and its electrocatalytic activity. Notably, introducing heteroatoms such as nitrogen and sulfur into carbon materials showed a clear positive relationship between heteroatom incorporation and edge density (Figs. 6(A) and (B)). This finding highlights the role of edge sites as stable anchoring points for heteroatoms within the carbon framework. The interplay between edge structures and synergistic co-doping effects significantly enhances the electrocatalytic properties of carbon materials, driving spin redistribution and charge delocalization among adjacent carbon atoms and creating additional active sites. Defects within the carbon lattice play a crucial role in facilitating electron transfer. In graphene and carbon nanotube structures, intrinsic defects (such as atomic vacancies, pentagonal carbon rings, defects, and grain boundaries) can disrupt the uniform charge density distribution by localizing π-electrons, thereby concentrating charge around non-hexagonal carbon rings or grain boundary regions [74,75]. Structural modifications can also lead to uneven charge density distributions between zigzag-edged regions and the basal plane. For instance, a single vacancy at the graphene edge can enhance the charge density of adjacent carbon atoms, rendering the positively charged atoms potential electrocatalytic active sites [76]. The efficiency of defect–induced electron transfer is highly dependent on the location of the defects and the projection properties of non-hexagonal grain boundaries (Figs. 6(C)–(G)). 4 Carbon-based materials for electrocatalytic applications 4.1 Carbon-based materials for ORR ORR is an electrochemical process where oxygen molecules gain electrons and undergo reduction to form specific products. This reaction occurs at the cathode in devices such as fuel cells and metal-air batteries, playing a crucial role in determining the overall efficiency and performance of these energy systems. The efficiency of ORR directly influences key factors, including voltage output, energy conversion efficiency, and the long-term stability of the system. Due to its complexity, the ORR mechanism involves multiple electron transfer steps and proton migration, which complicates the understanding of its kinetics. Generally, ORR occurs via two primary pathways: the four-electron (4e–) pathway and the two-electron (2e–) pathway. The reaction equations for the four-electron pathway are as follows: (1) Alkaline conditions: O2 + 2H2O + 4e– → 4OH− (2) Acidic conditions: O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O Alternatively, ORR can follow a two-electron pathway, where hydrogen peroxide serves as an intermediate product. (3) Alkaline conditions: O2 + 2H2O + 2e− → H2O2 + 2OH− (4) Acidic conditions: O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → H2O2 In practice, the ORR typically involves a combination of both the four-electron and two-electron pathways. However, the four-electron pathway is generally preferred, as hydrogen peroxide produced via the two-electron pathway can be detrimental to the materials in electrochemical cells. In contrast, the four-electron pathway directly reduces oxygen to form water or hydroxide ions, thereby avoiding the generation of intermediate products. This pathway is more efficient because it directly converts oxygen into water or hydroxide ions, thereby improving the energy output and conversion efficiency of fuel cells and metal-air batteries [3,77]. Consequently, the number of electron transfers is a critical parameter in assessing the performance of ORR electrocatalysts. The ORR process consists of multiple steps, during which oxygen-containing intermediates adsorb onto the active sites of the electrocatalyst. Consequently, the ORR activity of the electrocatalyst is largely governed by the interaction strength between the active sites and the intermediates, which is characterized by adsorption energy. This adsorption energy is closely linked to the electronic structure of the active sites and can be modulated by tailoring the structure and composition of the electrocatalyst to enhance its electrocatalytic performance. Recent studies has increasingly focused on the development of carbon-based materials as ORR electrocatalysts. Among these, nitrogen-doped carbon materials, graphene-based composites, and metal-containing carbon materials have demonstrated significant potential. These materials not only offer a cost-effective alternative but also exhibit excellent structural stability, high surface area, and tunable electronic properties, all of which contribute to improved ORR performance. For instance, Zhang et al. [78] introduced nitrogen dopants and vacancy defects into monolayer graphene via plasma treatment to investigate their roles in ORR. Their findings indicate that vacancy defects significantly enhance ORR activity by reducing the overpotential and increasing current density. Meanwhile, nitrogen doping improves the selectivity of the two-electron pathway, thereby facilitating hydrogen peroxide formation. Further analysis suggests that vacancy defects play a pivotal role in improving ORR kinetics, whereas nitrogen doping primarily influences product selectivity [79]. The observed enhancement in ORR activity arises from the synergistic effect between vacancy defects and nitrogen doping in forming active sites (Figs. 7(A) –(C)). By strategically increasing vacancy defects and precisely controlling the nitrogen doping level, the ORR performance of monolayer graphene can be significantly optimized. Heteroatom-doped biomass-derived carbon materials have also been investigated as ORR electrocatalysts. For instance, Sun et al. [80] studied a nitrogen- and phosphorus-co-doped non-metallic porous catalyst (ABNP). The synergistic interaction between nitrogen and phosphorus increased the sp 3-hybridized carbon content in ABNP, resulting in a sustained enhancement of ORR activity (Figs. 7(D)–(F)). Density functional theory calculations provided insights into the underlying mechanism, revealing that the combined effect of nitrogen- and phosphorus-doping facilitates the adsorption and desorption of reaction intermediates at active sites, thereby improving ORR performance (Fig. 7(G)). Han et al. [81] developed a gas foaming and hard templating strategy to synthesize nitrogen- and sulfur-co-doped, layered ordered porous carbon (NSHOPC) as an efficient ORR electrocatalyst (Figs. 7(H)–(K)). They found that the nitrogen-sulfur co-doping induces significant synergistic effects, where sulfur doping generates defects and enhances charge accumulation on adjacent nitrogen atoms, thereby creating more active electrocatalytic sites (Fig. 7(L)). Benefiting from the layered ordered porous structure and high doping level, NSHOPC demonstrates excellent ORR activity. 4.2 Carbon-based materials for OER OER generates oxygen molecules in an aqueous electrolyte and serves as the reverse process of the ORR. It occurs in both acidic and basic environments and plays a crucial role in metal-air batteries charging and electrochemical water splitting at the anode. The OER pathway is strongly influenced by electrolyte pH. In acidic or neutral media, two water molecules undergo oxidation, releasing four protons and one oxygen molecule through the transfer of four electrons. In alkaline conditions, four hydroxyl ions participate in the reaction, yielding one oxygen molecule and two water molecules. The primary objective of electrocatalyst optimization is to reduce the energy barrier of the rate-determining step [82]. The OER reaction equations in acidic and alkaline solutions are as follows: (5) Alkaline conditions: 4OH– → O2 + 2H2O + 4e– (6) Acidic conditions: 2H2O → O2 + 4H+ + 4e– OER is critical to electrochemical water splitting and metal-air batteries, directly influencing their efficiency and performance. In water splitting, OER occurs at the anode, complementing the HER at the cathode, which is essential for hydrogen production. In metal-air batteries, OER takes place at the air cathode during charging, facilitating oxygen generation and supporting the recharge process. However, the high overpotential required for OER significantly limits the efficiency of both systems. Thus, the development of highly efficient electrocatalysts to reduce overpotential and enhance performance is of paramount importance. Carbon-based materials, particularly carbon nanotubes, graphene, and their derivatives, exhibit excellent electrocatalytic performance due to their high conductivity and large surface area. In addition to being cost-effective, they can be strategically designed to lower the overpotential in the OER process and enhance electrocatalytic efficiency. However, the high oxidation potential and gas bubble formation during OER often cause oxidation and structural degradation, compromising their long-term stability. To overcome this challenge, researchers have improved the oxidative resistance and electrocatalytic performance of carbon materials by doping with heteroatoms and optimizing their structure, such as incorporating porous networks [83,84]. Furthermore, hybridizing carbon materials with metal oxides or conductive polymers enhances their long-term stability. For instance, Murugan et al. [85] developed nitrogen-doped, defect-rich porous carbon nanosheets, exhibiting a large surface area (3369 m2 g–1), high pore volume (2.1 cm3 g–1), and excellent conductivity (12.69 S cm–1). Nitrogen doping improves conductivity and electron donor properties, expands graphite interlayer spacing, and generates abundant electroactive and defect sites (Figs. 8(A) –(C)). These structural features facilitate ion transport, enhance electrolyte permeability, and improve electrochemical reactivity, collectively leading to high OER activity. Park et al. [86] proposed a method for synthesizing highly crystalline carbon-encapsulated metal nanoparticle networks from a polyphenol tannic acid precursor and NiFe metals. Comparative studies demonstrated that carbon-encapsulated NiFe nanoparticles exhibited superior OER performance compared to unmodified NiFe or NiFe supported on amorphous carbon (Fig. 8(D)). This enhancement is primarily attributed to the graphite carbon shell, which mitigates carbon oxidation and prevents electrocatalyst leaching (Fig. 8(E)). Furthermore, embedding NiFe within the graphite shell improves crystallinity and graphitic properties, leading to enhanced OER activity and long-term durability (Fig. 8(F)). 4.3 Carbon-Based materials for HER HER is a fundamental electrochemical process in water splitting, essential for hydrogen production in clean energy technologies. Occurring at the cathode of electrochemical reactors, HER involves the reduction of water molecules to hydrogen gas. It follows two primary pathways: the Volmer-Heyrovsky and Volmer-Tafel mechanisms [87]. The HER reaction equations in acidic and alkaline solutions are as follows: (7) Alkaline conditions: 2H2O + 2e– → H2 + 2OH– (8) Acidic conditions: 2H+ + 2e– → H2 Unlike the ORR and OER processes where oxygen intermediates are adsorbed on active sites, in the HER process, hydrogen atoms adsorb onto the active sites and react with protons from the electrolyte and electrons from the electrode surface to form hydrogen molecules (Heyrovsky reaction). Additionally, two adjacent adsorbed hydrogen atoms can combine to generate hydrogen gas (Tafel reaction). Therefore, the selection of HER-active materials is primarily based on their hydrogen adsorption energy. Studies have shown that active sites with a hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔG H*) of zero typically provide the best HER activity [88]. Carbon materials, due to their unique structure and tunable surface properties, have garnered significant research interest. These materials offer considerable advantages for HER applications, including low cost, high conductivity, chemical stability, and adaptability. Carbon materials, such as graphene, carbon nanotube, and porous carbon, not only provide excellent electronic conductivity and large surface area, but also feature abundant reactive sites, thereby enhancing electrocatalytic performance [89]. Furthermore, doping with elements like nitrogen and boron, or surface modifications, can further optimize their electrocatalytic activity, improving both efficiency and stability. For instance, Wang et al. [90,91] synthesized a composite structure of carbon nanotube and porous carbon by co-pyrolyzing Ni-BDC-loaded carbon cloth with urea, embedding W-doped Ni nanoparticles onto the carbon cloth, and subsequently preparing NiW-CNT/PC/CC [92]. The incorporation of W optimized the electronic structure of Ni, while the high conductivity of carbon nanotube and the excellent mass transfer properties of porous carbon contributed to the exceptional HER performance (Figs. 9(A) and (B)). Liu et al. [93] prepared hollow Mo2C nanoreactors via carburization, in which carbon dots were in-situ generated on the surface, resulting in hollow CD@Mo2C-3 (Fig. 9(C) and (D)). This material demonstrated excellent HER performance in alkaline electrolytes, with the introduction of carbon dots shifting the d-band center of CD@Mo2C away from the Fermi level, thereby accelerating water dissociation and H* desorption (Figs. 9(E) and (F)). Cai et al. [94] coated CoP nanosheets on a 3D nanostructured current collector (N-CNT/CC) to prepare the CoP/N-CNT/CC electrocatalyst. The current collector was fabricated by in-situ growth of N-doped carbon nanotubes on carbon cloth. For CoP/N-CNT/CC, CoP directly participates in the HER reaction, while N-CNT promotes electron transport (Figs. 9(G) and (H)). Compared with CoP/CC without N-CNT, CoP/N-CNT/CC exhibited lower charge transfer resistance, indicating that N-CNT significantly accelerated electron transport. N-CNT expanded the current collector, preventing the aggregation of CoP nanosheets, increasing the contact area between CoP and the electrolyte, and exposing more active sites (Figs. 9(I) and (J)). DFT calculations indicated that the electron transfer bridge of N-CNT accelerated interface charge migration and reduced hydrogen adsorption energy, thereby enhancing HER kinetics. 4.4 Carbon-based materials for multifunctional electrocatalysis The demand for multifunctional electrocatalysts has been steadily rising due to their critical role in advanced energy conversion and storage technologies. In particular, bifunctional ORR and OER electrocatalysts are indispensable for metal-air batteries, while OER and HER bifunctional electrocatalysts are essential for efficient water splitting. Despite the distinct kinetic and thermodynamic requirements of ORR, OER, and HER, a single electrocatalyst can be engineered to achieve high electrocatalytic activity for multiple reactions through rational structural design, electronic modulation, and surface/interface engineering. The development of such multifunctional electrocatalysts not only simplifies the overall system architecture but also enhances efficiency, reduces costs, and promotes the practical implementation of next-generation energy technologies. 4.4.1 Carbon-based materials for ORR/OER bifunctional electrocatalysis Metal-air batteries are regarded as promising next-generation energy storage devices due to their exceptionally high theoretical capacity and energy density. In aqueous metal-air batteries, the ORR occurs at the air electrode during discharge, while the OER takes place during charge [95]. To minimize the overpotentials associated with both processes, highly efficient bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalysts are essential. The electrocatalytic activity of bifunctional electrocatalysts is primarily governed by the adsorption energy of oxygen-containing intermediates at the active sites. Theoretical studies reveal an inherent linear scaling relationship between the adsorption energies of these intermediates in ORR and OER pathways [96,97]. This scaling constraint fundamentally limits the ability of a single active site to achieve optimal electrocatalytic performance for both reactions simultaneously. However, through the strategic selection of compositions and rational design modifications, it is possible to disrupt this scaling relationship, thereby enabling the development of electrocatalysts with enhanced ORR and OER activities. To evaluate the bifunctional ORR/OER activity of electrocatalysts, the potential difference (ΔE) between the OER potential at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 (E 10) and the half-wave potential of ORR (E 1/2) is widely used as a benchmark. In addition, bifunctional activity can be assessed by integrating the electrocatalyst into the air electrode of an aqueous metal-air battery [98]. By analyzing the discharge/charge polarization curves and the constant-current charge-discharge cycling profiles, key performance metrics such as the charge-discharge voltage difference and round-trip efficiency can be extracted. These parameters provide direct insight into the ORR/OER bifunctional activity of the electrocatalyst under practical operating conditions. Since noble metal-based electrocatalysts typically exhibit high activity for either ORR or OER but not both, research on bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalysts has predominantly focused on carbon-based, non-noble metal materials. For instance, Cheng et al. [99] developed an innovative strategy by first synthesizing nitrogen- and phosphorus-doped defect-rich carbon nanosheets (N, P-DC) and subsequently non-thermally coating the doping sites with metal-N4 macrocyclic molecules, forming FePc@N, P-DC (Fig. 10(A) ). The introduction of defect-rich carbon facilitated the stabilization of the Fe center in a high-spin state, thereby significantly enhancing the ORR performance (Fig. 10(B)). The FePc@N, P-DC electrocatalyst exhibited a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.903 V and demonstrated excellent cycling stability in alkaline media. Theoretical calculations further indicated that the OER overpotential of FePc@N, P-DC was 0.52 V, substantially lower than the 0.80 V observed for N, P-DC, highlighting the critical role of metal-N4 macrocyclic molecules in reducing energy barriers and improving electrocatalytic efficiency (Figs. 10(C)–(E)). In another study, Zhang et al. [100] synthesized a novel and highly efficient mesoporous carbon material embedded with CoFe nanoclusters and coated with a graphite carbon layer, denoted as CoFe-FeNC. The electrocatalyst demonstrated excellent bifunctional electrocatalytic performance, exhibiting a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.876 V for the ORR in an alkaline solution and a potential of 1.526 V at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 for the OER (Figs. 10(F)–(I)). Theoretical calculations revealed that the incorporation of CoFe nanoclusters disrupted the highly symmetrical electronic structure of Fe–N–C, modulated the d-band center, and optimized the adsorption and desorption behavior of reaction intermediates, thereby enhancing overall electrocatalytic activity (Figs. 10(J) and (K)). Furthermore, a zinc-air battery employing CoFe-FeNC as the cathode material exhibited a high specific capacity of 767.5 mAh g-Zn –1 and an ultra-long operational lifespan exceeding 1200 h, highlighting its potential for practical energy applications. 4.4.2 Carbon-based materials for OER/HER bifunctional electrocatalysis The primary application of OER/HER bifunctional electrocatalysts lies in electrochemical water splitting, a key technology for sustainable hydrogen production. Efficient electrocatalysts with low overpotentials for both the OER and HER can significantly reduce the energy consumption of water electrolyzers, thereby improving overall efficiency. To assess the activity of OER/HER bifunctional electrocatalysts, several key parameters are commonly used. One crucial benchmark is the potential difference (ΔE) between the OER and HER at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 (E 10), which Ref. lects the overall voltage required to drive water splitting. Additionally, the cell voltage at a given current density, typically 10 mA cm–2, in a practical water electrolyzer serves as an important indicator of electrocatalytic performance, providing insight into the energy efficiency and operational feasibility of the electrocatalyst under real-world conditions. Lu et al. [101] reported the synergistic effect of ternary transition metal alloy nanoparticles (Zn, Co, Ni) embedded in a carbonized polypyrrole/carbon nanotube (Ppy/CNT) multilayer matrix (ZnCoNi/(Ppy/CNTs)4), demonstrating enhanced bifunctional electrocatalytic performance for the HER and OER (Fig. 11(A) ). In 1.0 mol L–1 KOH, ZnCoNi/(Ppy/CNTs)4 exhibits low overpotentials of 189 mV (OER) and 68 mV (HER) at 10 mA cm–2, highlighting its high activity. Electron transfer within the electrocatalyst modifies the electronic structure, reduces HER and OER energy barriers, increases active site density, and slightly elevates the density of states above the Fermi level, while effectively lowering interfacial electron transfer resistance, thereby enhancing overall electrocatalytic efficiency (Figs. 11(B) and (C)). Yu et al. [102] encapsulated Ni nanoparticles within carbon nanotubes grown on a three-dimensional conductive carbon framework, followed by phosphorization and selenization to generate dispersed P-doped NiSe2 nanoparticles (P-NiSe2@N-CNTs/NC). The carbon shell effectively protects these nanoparticles, ensuring highly exposed and stable active sites, which enhance HER and OER activity and accelerate reaction kinetics (Fig. 11(D)). In alkaline media, P-NiSe2@N-CNTs/NC exhibits low overpotentials of 95 mV (HER) and 306 mV (OER) at 10 mA cm–2, highlighting its excellent bifunctional electrocatalytic performance. P-doping reduces electron density around Ni while accumulating charge on Se, thereby lowering energy barriers for water dissociation and intermediate adsorption during HER and OER (Figs. 11(E) and (F)). When used as both the anode and cathode in an electrolyzer, P-NiSe2@N-CNTs/NC achieves a current density of 10 mA cm–2 at a low applied voltage of 1.609 V and demonstrates outstanding long-term stability. 4.4.3 Carbon-based materials for ORR/OER/HER trifunctional electrocatalysis Trifunctional electrocatalysts capable of catalyzing the ORR, OER, and HER hold great promise for applications in aqueous metal-air batteries and water electrolyzers. Moreover, integrating metal-air batteries with water electrolyzers enables the development of self-powered water-splitting systems, offering a sustainable approach to hydrogen production [103]. However, optimizing the electrocatalytic activity for ORR, OER, and HER within a single electrocatalyst is highly complex, as achieving optimal performance for all three reactions simultaneously presents significant challenges. The design of ORR/OER/HER trifunctional electrocatalysts typically prioritizes materials that already exhibit bifunctional activity, such as carbon-based materials and transition metal-based compounds [104]. Rational structural and compositional engineering, including heteroatom doping, nanostructuring, and defect modulation, is often employed to fine-tune the electronic structure and optimize active sites, thereby enhancing overall electrocatalytic performance. Jiang et al. [105] developed a nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheet (NCN-1000-5) via a self-generated gas foaming method, achieved by pyrolyzing a citric acid and NH4Cl mixture. This ultrathin nanosheet features abundant micropores, edge defects, and a high specific surface area (Fig. 12(A) ). Studies reveal that its intrinsic active sites reside at armchair edges adjacent to graphitic nitrogen-doped carbon atoms (Fig. 12(B)). NCN-1000-5 exhibits low overpotentials and excellent stability for ORR, OER, and HER, with OER and HER overpotentials of 320 and 90 mV, respectively, at 10 mA cm–2 (Figs. 12(C) and (E)). When applied in rechargeable zinc-air batteries, it delivers a high energy density (806 Wh kg cm–1), a low charge/discharge voltage difference (0.77 V), and an ultra-long cycling life exceeding 330 h at 10 mA cm–2 (Fig. 12(F)). Yang et al. [106] developed a trifunctional electrocatalyst, Fe3C-Co/NC, by encapsulating Fe3C and Co nanoparticles within a nitrogen-doped carbon layered structure using a simple template removal strategy. This hierarchical architecture, integrating 1D carbon nanotubes with 2D carbon nanosheets, synergistically enhances electrocatalytic performance (Fig. 12(D)). As a trifunctional electrocatalyst, Fe3C-Co/NC exhibits excellent activity in ORR, OER, and HER. In 0.1 M KOH, it achieves a high ORR half-wave potential of 0.885 V, with superior durability and methanol tolerance, outperforming Pt/C. In 1.0 mol L–1 KOH, the OER overpotentials at 10 and 100 mA cm–2 are 340 and 460 mV, respectively, demonstrating outstanding OER performance. Additionally, the electrocatalyst delivers high HER activity in both alkaline (238 mV) and acidic (298 mV) media (Figs. 12(G) and (H)). Taken together, carbon-based materials hold great promise for trifunctional electrocatalysis (Figs. 12(E) and (F)). Structural optimization, doping strategies, and integration with metals or metal oxides can significantly enhance their ORR, OER, and HER performance. These advancements lay a strong theoretical and technical foundation for developing efficient, stable, and cost-effective electrocatalysts. 4.5 Carbon-based materials for biomass electrooxidation Biomass, as the only sustainable carbon source, has gained attention as a viable alternative to fossil resources. In this context, the biorefinery of cellulosic biomass into fuels and feedstock chemicals offers a promising carbon-neutral route to reducing fossil fuel dependence. Biomass-derived platform chemicals serve as key intermediates for high-value oxygenated bio-chemicals used in pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, food additives, coatings, and liquid fuels. Traditional oxidation of biomass-derived feedstocks (e.g., glycerol, sorbitol, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural) relies on stoichiometric oxygen or excess chemical oxidants (e.g., peroxide, ozone) under harsh conditions, requiring high temperatures/pressures and toxic or expensive reagents. These methods suffer from poor selectivity, low yields, and excessive waste generation, limiting scalability and feasibility in distributed rural areas rich in biomass resources. To address these challenges, green catalytic strategies have attracted significant interest for producing fuels and fine bio-chemicals via cleaner and more sustainable routes. Electrocatalysis, extensively developed for water splitting and fuel cells, remains in its infancy for biomass upgrading but offers distinct advantages over thermochemical conversion: (1) operation under ambient conditions; (2) use of H2O as an oxygen source, eliminating chemical oxidants; (3) miniaturization and deployment near biomass sources; (4) integration with valuable cathodic reactions, such as hydrogen evolution and CO2 reduction; (5) cost competitiveness due to the increasing availability of renewable electricity; and (6) tunable product selectivity via applied potential or electrocatalyst design. Given these benefits, electrosynthesis of fine bio-chemicals from biomass feedstocks has emerged as a growing research focus, with increasing efforts directed toward developing efficient electrocatalysts. 4.5.1 Carbon-based materials for glycerol electrooxidation Glycerol, a major by-product of biodiesel production, is recognized as a valuable platform feedstock for producing high-value commodity chemicals. It has been listed among the top twelve biomass-derived platform molecules by the U.S. Department of Energy [107,108]. Glycerol can be converted into various fine bio-chemicals, including glyceraldehyde, dihydroxyacetone, glyceric acid, tartronic acid, glycolic acid, and formic acid, compounds with market values several times higher than glycerol itself [109]. Electrocatalytic oxidation offers a promising route for glycerol valorization. As a C3 polyol with three hydroxyl (–OH) groups, glycerol undergoes complex oxidation pathways involving multiple intermediates and C3–C1 products [110]. As illustrated in Fig. 13(A) , oxidation of a primary or secondary hydroxyl group yields glyceraldehyde or dihydroxyacetone, respectively. Glyceraldehyde can be further oxidized to glyceric acid, while dihydroxyacetone converts to hydroxypyruvic acid. Subsequent oxidation of glyceric acid leads to tartronic acid. For C2 products, C–C bond cleavage of glyceric acid preferentially forms glycolic acid, with formic acid as a by-product. Further two-electron oxidative cleavage of glycolic acid ultimately yields formic acid as a C1 product. Currently, noble metal-based materials are the most efficient electrocatalysts for glycerol oxidation. The influence of carbon substrates on Pt activity was investigated by electrodepositing Pt onto various carbon supports, including MWCNTs, graphene nanoribbons (GNRs), graphene oxide nanoribbons (GONRs), and carbon Vulcan (CV) [111]. Electrochemical analysis revealed significant differences in electrocatalytic activity, following the trend Pt/GNRs > Pt/CV > Pt/MWCNTs > Pt/GONRs. However, onset potential measurements showed similar values across all electrocatalysts, indicating that the carbon supports did not enhance glycerol oxidation in terms of onset potential or reduce activation energy. The primary contribution of carbon supports appears to stem from their influence on collision frequency. GNRs, with their high length-to-width ratio, facilitated uniform Pt dispersion, yielding smaller particle sizes and higher active site exposure. This improved the collision frequency between glycerol reactants and active sites, thereby enhancing specific activity. These findings highlight the role of carbon supports in reducing noble metal particle size and improving electrocatalyst utilization, ultimately boosting glycerol electrooxidation performance. Due to the low cost and abundant availability, carbon-supported non-noble metal electrocatalysts are promising alternatives to precious metals for glycerol electrooxidation. For instance, Han et al. [20] utilized three-dimensional hydrophilic carbon fiber paper as a support to grow a series of earth-abundant cobalt-based spinel oxides (MCo2O4, M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) and systematically evaluated their electrochemical performance. The hydrophilic treatment introduced functional groups that acted as nucleation sites for metal ion anchoring, facilitating uniform distribution of spinel oxide nanostructures while preventing aggregation (Fig. 13(B)). As a result, MCo2O4 nanostructures grew vertically and uniformly across the carbon fiber paper surface. Electrochemical measurements revealed distinct glycerol oxidation activities among the MCo2O4 series (Figs. 13(C) and (D)). Notably, when arranged by increasing atomic number, their intrinsic activities followed a pyramid-shaped trend, with CuCo2O4 at the apex (Fig. 13(E)). Bulk electrolysis experiments further demonstrated that CuCo2O4 primarily produced formic acid, with glyceric acid and glycolic acid as by-products (Fig. 13(F)) [55]. 4.5.2 Carbon-based materials for HMF electrooxidation HMF is another key biomass-derived platform molecule, produced via hexose dehydration (e.g., glucose, fructose) [112]. Unlike glycerol, HMF has a more complex structure, containing aldehyde and hydroxyl groups fused with a furan ring, which compromises its chemical stability in alkaline systems. HMF can be selectively oxidized into 5-hydroxymethyl-2- furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-formyl-2- furancarboxylic acid (FFCA), and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) [113]. Among these, FDCA has gained significant interest as a key monomer for bio-based polymer synthesis. Interestingly, despite the complex molecular structure of HMF, the electrosynthesis of FDCA is independent of the reaction pathway [114]. As shown in Fig. 14(A) , HMF electrooxidation first yields HMFCA or DFF, both of which subsequently convert to FFCA and ultimately to FDCA. Highly efficient electrocatalysts are crucial for HMF electrooxidation, with carbon-supported noble metal electrocatalysts widely explored for HMF-to-FDCA conversion. For example, a tunable multilayer hybrid of graphene oxide and bimetallic AuPd nanoparticles was developed for HMF electrooxidation [115]. In this system, nanosized graphene oxide, enriched with negative charges, served as a scaffold to immobilize positively charged AuPd nanoparticles via electrostatic interactions. The internal architecture and thickness were precisely controlled using layer-by-layer assembly. Electrochemical studies revealed that bimetallic AuPd electrocatalysts exhibited significantly enhanced HMF oxidation activity compared to their monometallic counterparts [116]. Mechanistic investigations confirmed a sequential oxidation pathway from HMF to HMFCA to FFCA. Product selectivity is highly dependent on applied potential and electrocatalyst composition, with optimized performance achieved at 0.9 VRHE, yielding 83% FDCA for the PdAu2/C electrocatalyst. To expand the range of alternative electrocatalysts, three-dimensional carbon fiber paper-supported NiFe layered double hydroxide (NiFe-LDH) was developed as efficient noble metal-free electrocatalyst for HMF electrooxidation [117]. The hydrophilic-treated carbon fiber paper, featuring negatively charged functional groups, facilitated the adsorption of positively charged metal ions, enabling the in-situ growth of NiFe-LDH (Fig. 14(B)) [118]. The electrocatalyst was directly employed as the anode for HMF electrooxidation performance evaluation (Fig. 14(C)). Compared to other Ni-based materials (Ni(OH)2, NiAl-LDH, and NiGa–LDH), NiFe-LDH exhibited superior electrochemical activity, highlighting the critical role of Fe species in enhancing electrocatalytic performance (Fig. 14(D)). Product distribution analysis at different potentials revealed high selectivity toward FDCA, with only trace amounts (< 1%) of FFCA detected (Fig. 14(E)). Notably, common by-products such as DFF and HMFCA, typically observed in noble metal-catalyzed HMF oxidation, were absent, further confirming the high selectivity (Figs. 14(F) and (G)). 4.6 Carbon-based materials for other electrocatalytic applications The carbon dioxide reduction reaction is an emerging green technology that electrochemically converts CO2 into value–added chemicals and fuels, offering a dual benefit of mitigating greenhouse gas emissions while enabling efficient storage and utilization of renewable energy. Despite its potential, CO2RR faces significant challenges due to the intrinsic chemical stability of CO2 molecules and the complex multi-electron transfer pathways involved, leading to issues with selectivity, energy efficiency, and reaction kinetics [119]. Overcoming these obstacles requires the rational design and optimization of electrocatalysts to lower reaction overpotentials and enhance product selectivity. Recent research has increasingly focused on advanced electrocatalytic materials, particularly single-atom catalysts (SACs) supported on carbon frameworks, which offer well-defined active sites, high atomic utilization, and tunable electronic structures, making them highly promising for achieving efficient and selective CO2 conversion. For instance, copper-based SACs exhibit remarkable selectivity in CO2 reduction, facilitating the production of valuable products such as carbon monoxide and methanol. Wang et al. [120] designed and constructed a nickel single-atom catalyst based on a three-dimensional interconnected nitrogen-doped carbon tube (NiSAs@3D-INCT) network, which serves as an efficient and stable CO2RR self-supported electrode. Benefiting from the interconnected and layered channels supported by 3D-INCT, high-density atomically isolated nickel single atoms were successfully loaded, significantly enhancing the intrinsic activity of CO2RR (Figs. 15(A) and (B)). At the same time, the unique tubular network structure of NiSAs@3D-INCT greatly facilitated CO2 diffusion and electrolyte transport, further accelerating the electrocatalytic reaction kinetics. The synergistic effect between the high-density active sites and efficient mass transfer significantly improved its overall performance in CO2RR (Figs. 15(C) and (D)). Therefore, as a self-supported, binder-free NiSAs@3D-INCT electrode, it exhibited an extraordinary current density of 51.8 mA cm–2 and a Faradaic efficiency of 91.4% at –0.96 V. DFT calculations indicate that the Ni-N4 sites are the highly active sites for CO2RR in NiSAs@3D-INCT. The Nitrogen Reduction Reaction is an electrochemical process that directly converts nitrogen gas into ammonia, providing a sustainable alternative to the energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process. Ammonia, an essential chemical for agriculture and industry, is in constant high demand; however, conventional synthesis methods require extreme conditions and contribute significantly to global greenhouse gas emissions. In contrast, NRR enables nitrogen fixation under ambient temperature and pressure through an electrocatalytic mechanism, offering a more energy-efficient and environmentally friendly approach. Despite its potential, NRR faces substantial challenges due to the high dissociation energy of the nitrogen triple bond and the competitive HER, which hinders selectivity. To address these limitations, SACs supported on carbon materials have emerged as promising candidates, providing well-defined active sites, enhanced catalytic efficiency, and improved selectivity for nitrogen reduction. By precisely tuning the electronic structure and coordination environment of SACs, researchers continue to push the boundaries of NRR technology, bringing it closer to practical application. For instance, iron-based SACs play a crucial role in nitrogen reduction by effectively lowering the activation energy barrier for N2 molecules, thereby enhancing ammonia synthesis. Kong et al. [121] developed an efficient D-FeN/C electrocatalyst through a simplified electrospinning-pyrolysis method. This catalyst consists of atomically dispersed Fe–N4 sites anchored on porous carbon nanofibers with abundant intrinsic carbon defects. Benefiting from the synergistic effect of atomically dispersed Fe–N4 sites and the auxiliary role of intrinsic carbon defects, the newly developed Fe single-atom catalyst exhibits excellent performance in NRR (Figs. 15(E) and (F)). At –0.4 V, this catalyst demonstrates a high Faradaic efficiency (FE) of approximately 15.8% and an NH3 yield of approximately 24.8 μg NH3 h–1 mgcat –1, along with excellent NRR stability, making it one of the most promising NRR electrocatalysts to date (Figs. 15(G) and (H)). Combined experimental observations and DFT calculations indicate that the Fe–N4 active sites with intrinsic carbon defects accelerate the rate of the hydrolysis step and lower the energy barrier for N2 protonation, thereby facilitating proton–coupled NRR (Fig. 15(I)). This work accelerates protonation kinetics to achieve favorable NRR and various important electrochemical applications. By precisely tuning the surface chemistry of carbon supports and modulating the electronic structure of single-atom sites, the electrocatalytic activity, selectivity, and stability of these reactions can be further optimized, paving the way for more efficient and sustainable electrochemical conversion processes. 5 Conclusions and perspectives The development of functional carbon-based materials for advanced electrocatalysis has become an increasingly prominent research focus. In this review, we provide a comprehensive summary of recent advancements, encompassing strategies for the functionalization of multi-dimensional carbon materials, approaches for structural design and modulation, as well as their diverse applications in electrocatalysis. Despite significant progress, the realization of carbon-based electrocatalysts with both high activity and long-term stability for practical applications remains a formidable challenge. Further research efforts should focus on the following aspects: 5.1 Precise regulation of carbon materials The application of carbon-based materials in electrocatalysis continues to face significant challenges, among which precise structural modulation remains a central research focus. To further optimize their electronic structure, electrocatalytic activity, and mechanical properties, it is essential to achieve multi-scale precision control, spanning from the nanoscale to the mesoscale and macroscale [122]. At present, research efforts are primarily directed toward tuning the electron density by introducing structural defects such as vacancies, edges, steps, and strain. These modifications serve to enhance electrocatalytic activity and electrical conductivity (Figs. 16(A) and (B)). However, a critical challenge for future development lies in the precise quantitative control of defect types and concentrations. By integrating theoretical calculations, researchers aim to accurately predict the optimal defect configurations, thereby improving both the stability and electrocatalytic efficiency of carbon materials. Beyond defect engineering, doping strategies have emerged as a powerful approach for modulating the electronic and electrocatalytic properties of carbon materials. Single-element doping (e.g., N, P, S, B) and dual-element co-doping (e.g., N–S, N–P, B–N) have been extensively employed to tailor the electronic structure, significantly enhancing electrocatalytic activity [128–130]. Future research will delve deeper into non-uniform doping strategies, aiming to create gradient distributions that can fine-tune electrocatalytic selectivity. Additionally, self-assembled doping techniques inspired by biomaterial formation processes will be explored, enabling adaptive regulation of material properties at multiple scales. Moreover, advancements in single-atom dispersed metal doping will be pursued to maximize atomic utilization and further enhance electrocatalytic performance. These optimization strategies collectively hold great promise for accelerating the practical application of carbon–based materials in next-generation energy conversion, energy storage, and electrocatalysis. By addressing current challenges and leveraging cutting-edge material design principles, the development of highly efficient electrocatalytic materials will be significantly advanced, paving the way for more sustainable and high-performance energy technologies. 5.2 Development of renewable carbon materials With the growing global emphasis on environmental sustainability, the synthesis of carbon materials is expected to shift toward energy-efficient, environmentally friendly, and renewable-resource-based approaches [123,131]. Among these strategies, high-selectivity carbonization technology will play a pivotal role. By leveraging directional pyrolysis and catalytically assisted carbonization, researchers can further enhance the crystallinity, functionalization, and overall physicochemical properties of carbon materials (Fig. 16(C)). Additionally, functional surface modifications will be crucial for tailoring material performance. Techniques such as acid-base treatment, surfactant modification, and ion exchange will be employed to systematically improve electrical conductivity, hydrophilicity, and electrocatalytic activity, thereby expanding the functional versatility of carbon-based electrocatalysts [90]. In the broader context of sustainable development, the utilization of renewable resources will be central to the green synthesis of carbon materials.
