Future research efforts will actively explore biomass-derived feedstocks, including marine organisms (e.g., algae) and agricultural byproducts (e.g., straw, coconut shells), to enable the scalable and environmentally benign production of high-performance carbon materials [132–134]. This approach not only mitigates the environmental footprint associated with conventional material synthesis, but also fosters the widespread application of carbon-based materials in emerging fields such as renewable energy conversion, electrocatalysis, and environmental remediation. Ultimately, these advancements will serve as critical technological enablers for achieving carbon neutrality and advancing a more sustainable global energy infrastructure. 5.3 High-resolution techniques for depth characterization The continuous advancement of carbon-based electrocatalysis research has spurred the development of emerging characterization techniques, offering new opportunities for analyzing carbon materials. The rapid progress in nanoscale carbon materials has intensified the demand for sub-nanometer resolution and ultrafast dynamics studies, enabling more precise structural analysis and performance optimization. In electron microscopy, advances in low-dose TEM and aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) now allow ultrahigh-resolution imaging (< 0.5 Å), facilitating detailed analysis of layered structures, defects, and dopant atoms (Fig. 16(G)) [126,135]. Notably, low-dose TEM minimizes beam-induced damage, making it particularly suitable for flexible and bio-derived carbon materials [136]. The integration of 4D-STEM has further enhanced atomic-scale electronic structure characterization, enabling precise identification of active sites (Fig. 16(E)) [124]. Meanwhile, ongoing advancements in environmental transmission electron microscopy (ETEM), particularly in in-situ environmental control (e.g., gas atmosphere, electric field, and temperature variations), allow real-time monitoring of electrocatalytic reactions and morphological evolution. These innovations provide critical insights into electrocatalytic mechanisms, driving the fundamental understanding and optimization of carbon–based electrocatalysts. In the field of ultrafast spectroscopy, femtosecond transient absorption spectroscopy (TA) and femtosecond time-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy (TRPES) have emerged as powerful tools for probing the electronic excitation dynamics of carbon-based materials, such as graphene and carbon quantum dots [137]. These techniques provide critical insights into charge transfer processes, carrier recombination mechanisms, and exciton dynamics, which are essential for optimizing the optoelectronic and photocatalytic performance of these materials. By capturing ultrafast electron and energy transfer events on femtosecond to picosecond timescales, these methods enable a deeper understanding of photoinduced processes, thereby guiding the rational design of next-generation photodetectors, solar cells, and photocatalysts. 5.4 Advanced techniques for in-situ observation Beyond optical spectroscopy, X-ray free electron lasers (XFEL), when combined with X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), enable real–time tracking of the structural evolution of carbon materials under operando conditions in electrocatalysis and energy storage systems [138–140]. These techniques provide unprecedented spatial and temporal resolution, allowing researchers to monitor phase transitions, defect dynamics, and electronic structure changes during electrocatalytic reactions and charge-discharge cycles. Such real-time insights offer a fundamental theoretical basis for the precise design and optimization of high-performance carbon-based electrocatalysts, accelerating breakthroughs in energy conversion, storage technologies, and sustainable energy applications. Advancements in in-situ TEM and spectroscopic techniques have revolutionized real-time monitoring, structural optimization, and mechanistic analysis [141]. In-situ TEM enables direct observation of electrocatalyst evolution under high- temperature, gas/liquid-phase, and electrochemical conditions, unveiling intrinsic structural changes in carbon materials, such as graphene defect formation and recovery. In-situ Raman spectroscopy excels in tracking phase transitions and electrocatalytic intermediates, deepening mechanistic insights into key electrocatalytic reactions (Fig. 16(F)) [125]. Likewise, in-situ Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) reveals surface adsorption behaviors and electrocatalytic pathways [142]. Moreover, synchrotron-based X-ray spectroscopy (XPS/XAS), coupled with in-situ electrochemical cells, enables real-time tracking of active site evolution, offering critical guidance for the rational design of next-generation electrocatalysts [143]. As high-precision, high-time-resolution characterization techniques continue to evolve, their integration with multi-modal methodologies will provide a more comprehensive understanding of electrocatalytic mechanisms in carbon materials. This progress will accelerate the application of carbon materials in energy conversion, storage, and electrocatalysis, while paving the way for industrial-scale development of high-performance carbon-based electrocatalysts. 5.5 Intelligent manufacturing and response The integration of machine learning (ML), artificial intelligence (AI), and computational simulations is revolutionizing the design and optimization of carbon materials, ushering in a new data-driven era [144]. First-principles calculations and molecular dynamics simulations enable precise predictions of optimal structures, electronic properties, and functionalization strategies, significantly enhancing the efficiency and accuracy of material design (Fig. 16(D)). Furthermore, machine learning-assisted material discovery, leveraging vast datasets and high-throughput screening, accelerates the identification of novel carbon materials, refines synthesis protocols, and provides theoretical guidance for improving catalytic activity, conductivity, and mechanical stability [145]. These computational advancements not only drastically shorten the material development cycle but also improve the feasibility of carbon materials in applications such as renewable energy conversion, electrocatalysis, and next-generation electronic devices. For example, Li et al. [146] systematically and comprehensively introduced porous carbon materials (PCM), covering traditional synthesis methods, machine learning-assisted design principles, and their applications in energy storage and conversion. They thoroughly summarized the preparation methods for microporous, mesoporous, macroporous, and layered porous carbon materials, with a focus on structural control rules and formation mechanisms, highlighting the unique advantages of PCM in alkali metal ion batteries, metal-sulfur batteries, supercapacitors, and electrocatalysis. Beyond computational innovation, the emergence of intelligent, responsive carbon materials is shaping the next frontier of material science. By leveraging their intrinsic physicochemical properties and external stimulus responsiveness, researchers are actively developing adaptive carbon materials that exhibit high sensitivity to temperature, light, mechanical stress, and electric fields (Fig. 16(H)) [127]. A prime example is the self-healing carbon-based electrodes, which autonomously repair structural defects, extending device lifespan and enhancing long-term electrochemical performance. Similarly, dynamically tunable electrocatalysts, capable of adjusting their active sites in response to environmental changes, significantly boost electrocatalytic efficiency and stability [147,148]. 5.6 Future application prospects With the deepening integration of multiple disciplines, carbon materials are evolving toward multifunctional integration across electrocatalysis, electrochemical energy storage, and sensing, unlocking immense potential in both cutting-edge technologies and industrial applications. Among these, the field of flexible electronic devices has particularly benefited from the unique advantages of carbon materials, including exceptional electrical conductivity, mechanical flexibility, high surface area, and tunable structural properties. These attributes position carbon materials as next-generation intelligent materials capable of addressing the growing demands for high-performance, durable, and adaptable electronic systems. In recent years, the development of self-supporting carbon architectures has provided a transformative strategy for high-performance flexible electronics, eliminating the need for additional binders and enabling the construction of lightweight, stable, and highly conductive carbon frameworks. Notable examples include graphene aerogels, carbon nanotube films, and electrospun carbon nanofibers, which exhibit enhanced mechanical robustness, electrical conductivity, and electrochemical stability. These advancements have not only improved energy storage devices, such as flexible supercapacitors and lithium-ion batteries, but also expanded the functional scope of next-generation electronic textiles and stretchable circuits. Furthermore, the emergence of intelligent carbon-based flexible sensors, integrated with nanoscale interface engineering and functionalized surface modifications, has significantly enhanced sensitivity, selectivity, and real-time responsiveness to external stimuli, including mechanical stress, temperature fluctuations, biochemical signals, and electric fields. These innovations have laid a solid foundation for future wearable electronics, smart healthcare monitoring systems, human-machine interaction technologies, and neuromorphic computing interfaces. As research continues to push the boundaries of material design and functional integration, carbon-based flexible electronics are poised to revolutionize next-generation smart devices, bridging the gap between advanced materials and practical, large-scale applications. Kun Zhang (School of Chemical Engineering, Northeast Electric Power University) received his Ph.D. degree from Dalian University of Technology in 2020. In the same year, he joined the Guangzhou Branch of Sinopec Corporation. Since 2022, he has been working at Northeast Electric Power University. His research focuses on energy materials and electrocatalysis, with an emphasis on the design of novel electrocatalysts for hydrogen production. His recent work includes the synthesis of hollow-structured materials with superior electrocatalytic performance and the development of metal- and nonmetal-ion-doped electrocatalysts derived from metal organic frameworks (MOFs) with excellent overall water splitting activity. To date, he has published more than 20 peer-reviewed papers. Xiaotong Han (School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University) received his B.A. degree from Nanjing Tech University (P. R. China) in 2013, and Ph.D. degree from Dalian University of Technology in 2019. He carried out postdoctoral research at Sungkyunkwan University (Republic of Korea) from 2019 to 2022. Since May of 2022, he has been working in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University. His research interests focus on surface/interface engineering of energy materials and their applications in water splitting, organic electrosynthesis, biomass electrooxidation, electrocatalytic epoxidation of olefins, and zinc-air batteries. To date, he has published more than 70 peer-reviewed papers. Jieshan Qiu (College of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology) received his Ph.D. degree in Organic Chemical Engineering in 1990 from Dalian University of Technology. Currently, he is Cheung-Kong Distinguished Professor of Carbon Science and Chemical Engineering. He is an internationally recognized research and thought leader in carbon science and chemical engineering. His research encompasses both fundamental and applied aspects of carbon materials and science, with a focus on the methodologies for producing carbon materials and their applications in catalysis, energy storage and conversion. He has published more than 800 peer-reviewed papers.

coredata.dc:description: Functional carbon-based materials have become a key research direction in the field of advanced electrocatalysis due to their unique structure and properties. Various strategies have been proposed to design and synthesize high-performance carbon-based electrocatalysts. In this review, we comprehensively summarize the latest developments in carbon-based materials for advanced electrocatalysis, with particular emphasis on the structure design strategies and the intrinsic relationship between structure, activity, and performance. The functionalization of multi-dimensional carbon-based materials with enhanced electrocatalytic performance is first addressed. Next, the impact of electronic and structural engineering on the performance of carbon-based materials for electrocatalysis is discussed in terms of the advantages of different types of carbon-based materials in electrocatalytic applications. Finally, the prospects in areas such as precise tuning of functional carbon-based materials, the development of renewable carbon materials, the use of advanced characterization techniques and the promotion of smart manufacturing and responsiveness are highlighted.
